text:
Good morning dear family,
friends, faculty, Dean Datar,
distinguished speakers.

And good morning to the
great Class of 2021.
My name is Caleb Bradford.

I am one of your Student
Association Co-Presidents,

and a proud member of
Section B. Together,

Annie and I have had
the tremendous honor

of representing you
over the past year.

Originally, I'm from
Sweet Home Alabama.

And I'm blessed to have not only
four brothers, but four sisters
as well.

My parents separated
when I was six.

Afterward, and my father fought
for and won custody of me.

Growing up, I suffered from
severe anxiety and depression,

watched my oldest brother
Aris die when I was 11,

witnesses is the
rest of my brothers

drop out of high school
and get incarcerated,

and even faced housing
insecurity for a time.

My experience as a low income
first generation college

student was akin to
walking a tightrope.

With an anchor braced
around my ankles,

that anchor symbolized the
constant familial, financial,

and related stressors that
compounded the normal load
carried by a student.

But the balancing act wasn't
even the hardest part.

It was looking down and
realizing there was no safety
net to catch me if I fell.

Now, even though I grew up
in poverty, I was lucky.

Because unlike my
older siblings,

and while I did nothing to
deserve it more than they did,

I was blessed with
a dad who cared,

who believed in me, who
repeatedly sacrificed so that I

could fulfill my dreams, and
who through his parenting,

instilled in me the
importance of education.

And though I didn't
live with them,

I always had the
love and support
of my mother and older siblings.

It's true that no
one succeeds alone.

My family, friends, and mentors
all served as the rocket fuel,
propelling me here today.

Now, in coming to HBS, I was
clear-eyed about the impact
I wanted to make.

You see, I know
my older siblings
have incredible ability.

They just didn't have the
opportunity I was given.

Thus I was inspired to run
for Student Association

Co-President, to create
more opportunity for those

who will come after me and
cultivate a sense of belonging
for all our students.

However, not even two weeks
into our term as Co-Presidents,

our community focus had to
pivot to confronting COVID-19.
But we didn't do this alone.

The deep partnership we
have between faculty, staff,

and students allowed us to
build robust virtual and
hyper-classroom capabilities.

We're also thankful for our
custodial staff and Restaurant

Associates teams, who ensured
we had sanitary living spaces
and safe food to pick up.

Two months after COVID
hit our community,
we confronted another pandemic--
systemic racism.

Personally, I'm grateful
to our entire team, who

for the first time
in HBS history,

worked tirelessly
over the summer
to respond to these challenges.

We safely hosted events
and fostered community
despite COVID.

But we also
significantly advanced

the level of diversity
and inclusion at HBS.

We launched a new DEI
section leadership role,

expanded diversity in
the school curriculum

through the Juneteenth
case pledge,

and held critical positions
on the Dean's Anti-Racism Task
Force.

Looking back, our community
has a lot to be proud of.

For us, social distancing did
not mean emotional distancing.

We generated laughter and fun
through the HBS Show and HBS
Got Talent.

And we celebrated
moments of pure joy.

Quarantine babies were
born, y'all, proposals made,

pets adopted, plants sprouted,
sourdough bread baked.

Together, we discovered
that uncertainty

demands that we know more, that
we care more, that we do more.

Our character and our commitment
is reflected in these times.

I have seen you
summon the courage

to be allies and accomplices
for our minority communities,

as the struggle for equality
and justice continues.

I have seen you
launch new businesses
to help combat COVID-19.

I've seen you manage
school and work

in the health during a
pandemic, all the while

constantly being there
to support one another.
We have all seen it.

Today, we become graduates of
the Harvard Business School.

But the past year taught us that
the currency that matters most
is not money.

It's not data, but the
meaningful relationships

we have and the level
of care we show.

Our bonds were forged
in crisis, and our class

will encounter more crucible
moments in the years ahead.

There will be times when
you may feel overwhelmed,

when you stumble make mistakes,
times where the path forward
is unclear.

However, if we
recommit ourselves

to the journey of mindfully
living and meaningfully

working, then our
talent and resilience
will lead us to our North Star.

And to achieve this, I
ask of you three things.
First, embrace vulnerability.
It is fundamental to connection.
To be vulnerable is to be alive.

If it is precisely our cuts,
our scars, our bruises,

the broken parts of us
that make us beautiful.

And it is only by sharing these
broken parts that we can truly
heal and become whole.
Second knowledge is important.

But people often don't
care what you know
until they know that you care.

So continue to build
empathy, and never
forget those who got you here.

Third, always, always
pay it forward.

As you seek opportunities
to climb higher and higher,

remember to lift others
up along the way.

I know that we, the great
Class of 2021, can do this.

We can use these
values as our compass

towards growth, as
you've all served
as my compass towards growth.

And it has been the
greatest, greatest privilege

of my time at HBS to serve
as your Student Association
Co-President.

I believe the world desperately
needs better leadership.

And I'm not afraid by the
uncertainty and challenge
that lay before us.

I am excited, excited
that the world will soon

enjoy the generosity and
indomitable spirit that

has defined our community these
past two years, excited that we

will stay united as a
class, by saying yes

to hanging out, and saying
yes to time together.

But most importantly,
I am excited because I

know that when the moment meets
the mission we blazon here

at HBS, each of you
and our community

will find ways to truly
make a positive difference
in the world.

Thank you from the bottom of
my heart for your support,

and I cannot wait
to see you soon.
